assessment.title: Online Lecture Activity - Week 2 - UNIT III (Part 2 of 2)

material.mattext:
Online Lecture Activity Instructions

  • This is a self-paced activity.

  • There is no time limit.

  • You may repeat the lecture and questions as many times as needed.

  • Take notes as you go to help with understanding.

  • Complete the comprehension questions as you go through the lecture.

section.title: Section 1 - Quick Review of Conditional Probability

material.mattext:
Reviewing Conditional Probability

Reinforcing key ideas of conditional probability with a practical cricket example

Brief Introduction

In this lesson, we revisit the concept of conditional probability to strengthen your understanding of how prior events influence the likelihood of outcomes. Building on our earlier introduction, we now explore the idea through a detailed real-world case—using cricket performance statistics to see conditional probability in action. This review is designed to clarify the concept and emphasize the contrast between conditional and unconditional probabilities.

Motivating Questions

How does knowing that one event has occurred change the probability of another?
What does Cheteshwar Pujara’s performance data teach us about P(A ∥ B)?
Why is it important to distinguish between conditional and unconditional probabilities in data analysis?

Featured Video

Video Summary

This video reinforces the core idea of conditional probability using Cheteshwar Pujara’s cricket stats as a case study. You’ve already encountered the definition: the likelihood of event A occurring given that event B has happened, written as P(A ∥ B). Here, we look at how often Pujara converts fifties into centuries—16 out of 31 times—compared to his overall century rate of 16 out of 76 innings. This clear contrast (52% vs. 21%) vividly illustrates how conditioning changes probabilities. The video walks through this reasoning and concludes with the standard formula: P(B ∥ A) = P(A ∩ B) / P(A). It’s a focused and practical review to solidify your grasp of the concept before moving on to more formal tools and techniques.
Which of the following correctly represents the probability of Cheteshwar Pujara scoring a century given that he has already scored a fifty in the first innings?

section.title: Section 2 - A Deeper Look into the General Conjunction Rule

material.mattext:
Review: General Conjunction Rule

Connecting Conditional Probability with the “AND” Rule

Brief Introduction

This review lesson helps solidify the connection between the general conjunction rule and conditional probability. While earlier topics may have introduced these ideas separately, this video brings them together, showing how the general “AND” rule for probabilities relies fundamentally on conditional thinking. Through a dice-based example, it emphasizes why the restricted version of the rule (used for independent events) is insufficient when dependencies exist.

Motivating Questions

How does conditional probability inform the general conjunction rule?
Why is the restricted “AND” rule not always valid?
In what situations must we apply the general conjunction rule instead of assuming independence?

Featured Video

Video Summary

This review video revisits the general conjunction rule and clarifies its connection to conditional probability. After a brief refresher on the restricted conjunction rule (used for independent events), it uses a die-rolling example to show where this simpler approach fails. The video then introduces the full general rule: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B | A), highlighting how it relies on knowing the probability of one event given that another has occurred. This deeper understanding reinforces that conditional probability isn't just a side topic—it's central to accurately calculating joint probabilities in most real-world situations.

Let \(\scriptsize E\) be the event that a fair six-sided die roll is even, and \(\scriptsize P\) be the event that the roll is a prime number. According to the general conjunction rule, what is the probability \(\scriptsize P(E \cap P)\) of rolling a number that is both even and prime?

Law of Total Probability

Understanding how to compute the probability of an event based on partitions of the sample space.

Brief Introduction

The Law of Total Probability is a fundamental theorem in probability theory that allows us to evaluate the probability of an event by considering several mutually exclusive scenarios that partition the sample space. By breaking down complex problems into simpler components, this law becomes especially useful in real-world applications, such as risk analysis and decision-making processes.

Motivating Questions

How can we compute the probability of an event by considering different underlying causes?
What role do mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive events play in probability?
How does the Law of Total Probability connect to Bayes' Theorem?

Featured Video

Video Summary

This video introduces the Law of Total Probability with a visual breakdown of a sample space partitioned into mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive events (B₁, B₂, B₃). It demonstrates how any event A can be described as the union of intersections with these events, leading to the formula P(A) = Σ P(Bᵢ)P(A∥Bᵢ). Examples include a factory with three machines producing parts at different defect rates and an urn problem with varying conditional probabilities. The concept is reinforced with a tree diagram, showcasing how the law simplifies complex probabilistic problems and underpins Bayes’ Theorem.

Using the factory example where Machine 1 produces 60% of parts with 7% defective rate, Machine 2 produces 30% of parts with 15% defective rate, and Machine 3 produces 10% of parts with 30% defective rate, what is the probability that a randomly selected part is defective?

Tree Diagrams in Probability

Visualizing compound events using probability trees

Brief Introduction

Tree diagrams offer a powerful visual method for solving probability problems, particularly when dealing with sequential or compound events. By organizing outcomes and their probabilities in a branching structure, learners can easily track possible results and compute combined probabilities step by step.

Motivating Questions

How can we systematically list all possible outcomes of a multi-step event?
What rule helps us compute the probability of a sequence of events?
How do conditional probabilities affect the structure of a tree diagram?

Featured Video

Video Summary

This video introduces tree diagrams as a structured approach to visualize and calculate probabilities in multi-step experiments. Each branch in the tree represents a potential outcome and is labeled with the corresponding probability. The structure grows column by column as each stage of the experiment unfolds—for example, multiple coin tosses. A key principle is that probabilities branching from the same point must sum to one. To compute the likelihood of a particular path, the probabilities along that path are multiplied. An example using tourist visits to Big Ben and Trafalgar Square illustrates this with a final probability of 0.3. The video also explores how to verify a tree diagram's completeness by checking that all terminal probabilities sum to one and includes conditional probabilities, such as drawing without replacement. Viewers are invited to apply their understanding through a concluding practice problem.

In a probability tree diagram, the probabilities along all the branches that directly follow from the same point — that is, from the same split where an outcome occurs (like a coin toss or marble draw) — must always add up to 1.

section.title: Section 5 - Probability Trees: An Applied Problem

material.mattext:
Conditional Probability with Tree Diagrams

Using visual aids to understand how conditional probability works

Brief Introduction

Conditional probability is a key concept in statistics that helps you determine the likelihood of an event happening, given that another event has already occurred. In this lesson, you’ll learn how to use tree diagrams to break down and solve these types of problems. By following a real-world example and walking through each step visually and symbolically, you'll gain a deeper and more intuitive understanding of how conditional probability works.

Motivating Questions

How can tree diagrams help you visualize conditional probability problems?
What is the formula for conditional probability, and how do you apply it?
How do you interpret P(L ∥ B) in everyday situations?

Featured Video

Video Summary

In this video, you’ll learn how to calculate conditional probabilities using tree diagrams. You'll follow a scenario involving John’s commute: he takes the bus 80% of the time, and there's a 60% chance he’s late when he takes the bus. A tree diagram maps out the possible outcomes, helping you see how probabilities branch out. You'll be introduced to the conditional probability formula, P(A ∥ B) = P(A and B) / P(B), and use it to compute the likelihood of John being late given that he took the bus—resulting in a probability of 0.75. The video guides you through both symbolic and intuitive explanations, helping you become comfortable with the concept. You'll also apply the formula to other scenarios, such as finding the probability of not being late if John didn’t take the bus.
Given that \( \scriptsize P(B) = 0.8\) and \( \scriptsize P(B \cap L) = 0.6,\) what is the value of \( \scriptsize P(L \mid B)\)?

Understanding Bayes' Rule

How to update your beliefs using new evidence

Brief Introduction

Bayes' Rule is one of the most powerful ideas in probability and statistics. It helps you revise what you believe when you encounter new information. In this lesson, you'll explore how Bayes' Rule is derived, how to apply it, and why it's so useful in real-world decision-making. Whether you're dealing with colored balls in boxes or faulty computer chips, this tool will help you think clearly and quantitatively about uncertainty.

Motivating Questions

How do you derive Bayes' Rule from basic probability?
How can you use Bayes' Rule to update your belief in a hypothesis after seeing new evidence?
What is the base rate fallacy, and how can Bayes' Rule help you avoid it?

Featured Video

Video Summary

In this video, you'll dive into Bayes' Rule—a powerful formula that lets you revise your probability estimates as new evidence comes in. The lesson starts by walking you through how Bayes' Rule comes from the basic definition of conditional probability. Then, you'll see how to apply it to solve real problems. First, you'll look at two boxes containing red and green balls, and figure out which box a green ball likely came from. Then, you'll tackle a more complex example: determining whether a faulty computer chip came from a high-defect or low-defect company. You'll define variables, identify priors and conditionals, and plug everything into Bayes' formula. You'll also learn how easy it is to fall into the base rate fallacy—and how Bayes' Rule helps you avoid it by keeping your reasoning grounded in both prior information and new data.

In the defective-chip example, Company A supplies 100 chips (5% defective) and Company B supplies 300 chips (7% defective).

Let\[ \scriptsize A = \{\text{chip from Company A}\},\] 
\[ \scriptsize \quad B = \{\text{chip from Company B}\},\] 
\[ \scriptsize \quad D = \{\text{chip is defective}\}. \]

We know \( \scriptsize P(A) = 0.25\), \( \scriptsize P(B) = 0.75\), \( \scriptsize P(D \mid A) = 0.05\), and \( \scriptsize P(D \mid B) = 0.07\).

Compute the following conditional probability:

\[ \scriptsize  P\bigl(A \mid D^{\,c}\bigr)\;=\; P\bigl(\text{chip from A} \;\bigm|\;\text{chip is not defective}\bigr)\,?\]

And select the correct option:
